intro: Thelocactus ysabelae, commonly known as the Ysabel's cactus, is a rare and striking species native to a very limited area in Mexico. It is characterized by its tall, columnar stem and dense clusters of bright yellow flowers that bloom during the summer months. The plant has a unique ability to store water in its thick, fleshy stems, allowing it to survive in arid environments. Its flowers are typically short-lived but attract a variety of pollinators such as bees and moths. Due to its limited distribution and habitat threats, it is considered a vulnerable species in conservation efforts.
